Single trait association tests and summary statistics

Panagiotis Moulos

2022-06-06

Source: vignettes/06-gwasfuns.Rmd
06-gwasfuns.Rmd

Introduction

As a one-stop shop solution for the derivation of stable PRSs, PRISMA offers several methods to derive GWAS summary statistics. These summary statistics are then used to feed the PRS extraction process which is evaluated and reported in the end. The user is then able to select the best PRS or the PRS with combines relevant SNP content, reasonable number of SNPs and best evaluation metrics. The p-values of multiple tests can also be combined using one of the available p-value combination methods. See also the gwa() man page for details on the p-value combination.

PRISMA supports five methods for estimating SNP effects for single-trait associations. More specifically:

  1. General Linear Models (GLM): Each SNP is regressed against the phenotype and the selected covariates. An additive SNP effect model is assumed.
  2. Ridge regression through the R package rrBLUP. This package deploys penalized regression for shrinking the effects of less informative SNPs in relation with the phenotype.
  3. Single-trait association tests with the statgenGWAS R package. The association is based on linear regression and the incorporation of an internally calculated kinship matrix.
  4. Frequentist association tests with SNPTEST (Oxford). Each SNP is regressed against the phenotype and the selected covariates using an additive model (all other SNPTEST options are also supported).
  5. Association tests with PLINK (linear regression with covariates or simple X2 association tests if no covariates are present).

The SNP effects (regression coefficients and/or Odd Ratios) and p-values are reported in the end and registered to the related slots of the input GWASExperiment object. A GWASExperiment object can hold multiple results for the same genotypic/phenotypic data living in the object, as long as they are not the same models, i.e. a model with 2 PCs as covariates is different from a model with no PC covariates.

In the examples below we use the toy dataset included with PRISMA. For this reason we do not perform additional prior filtering although in a typical situation, genotypes should be filtered prior to any GWA testing. The main function for GWA testing is the gwa() function which attaches the results to the GWASExperiment object. Each GWA function (e.g. gwaGlm) can be used independently but it returns only a matrix of summary statistics. The following sections illustrate their usage.

Summary statistics with GLM

We test each SNP in the toy dataset for association with the main phenotype (BMI) given age, sex and case/control status, along with 1 PC. Below, we run GLM independently just to get summary statistics without attaching to the toy object.

data(toy,package="prisma")

gdsfile(toy) <- system.file(package="prisma","extdata","toy.gds")

# Only 1 PC will be returned because of dataset size
toy <- suppressWarnings(calcPcaCovar(toy,method="snprel"))
## Performing PCA to select covariates to include in associations
## Reading GDS file /tmp/RtmpezHjqb/temp_libpath372f48f1c2bc/prisma/extdata/toy.gds...
## Performing LD pruning...
## SNP pruning based on LD:
## Excluding 0 SNP (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 38 SNPs (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 962
##     using 1 thread
##     sliding window: 500,000 basepairs, Inf SNPs
##     |LD| threshold: 0.2
##     method: composite
## Chromosome 18: 23.44%, 154/657
## Chromosome 21: 21.28%, 73/343
## 227 markers are selected in total.
## LD pruning finished! 227 SNPs will be used for PCA.
## 
## Performing PCA...
## Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on genotypes:
## Excluding 773 SNPs (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 0 SNP (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 227
##     using 1 thread
##     # of principal components: 32
## PCA:    the sum of all selected genotypes (0,1,2) = 10268
## CPU capabilities: Double-Precision SSE2
## Mon Jun  6 20:32:06 2022    (internal increment: 13024)
## 
[..................................................]  0%, ETC: ---        
[==================================================] 100%, completed, 0s
## Mon Jun  6 20:32:06 2022    Begin (eigenvalues and eigenvectors)
## Mon Jun  6 20:32:06 2022    Done.
## Selecting number of PCs to include
##   with Tracy-Widom test for significant eigenvalues
##     selected 1 PCs

glmSumstat <- gwaGlm(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),pcs=TRUE)
## 
## Performing GWAS with GLM over 1 chunks
## Trait(s)    : BMI
## Covariate(s): Age, Gender
## Regression  : gaussian (predicted)
## Use PCs     : Yes
##   testing SNPs from rs1009238 to rs2828316
## Found 42 associations (uncorrected p-values).

The contents of the glmSumstat matrix:

head(glmSumstat)
##             Estimate Std. Error    t value   Pr(>|t|)
## rs1009238 -0.6695782  0.6649037 -1.0070303 0.31647832
## rs1940646  0.4810455  0.6722091  0.7156188 0.47598195
## rs1940651 -1.4435680  0.6911187 -2.0887412 0.03940511
## rs1940658 -0.9054984  0.6533306 -1.3859727 0.16900001
## rs1940670  0.8641098  0.6855611  1.2604417 0.21059720
## rs1954825  0.1746603  0.6480141  0.2695316 0.78810519

Now attach such results to the toy object with and without PCs

# With 1 PC
toy <- gwa(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),
    pcs=TRUE,psig=0.05,methods=c("glm"))
## 
## Starting GWA analysis in 2 chunks with 1 methods: glm
## 
## ========== Analyzing chromosome/part 18
## 
## Performing GWAS with GLM over 1 chunks

##   Part 18: 24 associations found out of 657 markers
##   Part 21: 18 associations found out of 343 markers
##

# With no PCs
toy <- gwa(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),
    pcs=FALSE,psig=0.05,methods=c("glm"))

Change the phenotype to Case_Control. Now, GLM will run in binomial regression mode as the Case_Control phenotype is binary.

# With 1 PC

    pcs=TRUE,psig=0.05,methods=c("glm"))

Now, use the listGwa() function to see what test results are attached to the toy object:

listGwa(toy)
## 1 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Gender | PCs: 1
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Gender + PC1 + [SNP]
## 2 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Gender | PCs: -
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Gender + [SNP]
## 3 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Case_Control, Gender | PCs: -
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Case_Control + Gender + [SNP]
## 4 -> Phenotype: Case_Control | Covariates: Age, BMI, Gender | PCs: 1
##      Putative formula: Case_Control ~ Age + BMI + Gender + PC1 + [SNP]
## 5 -> Phenotype: Case_Control | Covariates: Age, BMI, Gender | PCs: -
##      Putative formula: Case_Control ~ Age + BMI + Gender + [SNP]
## 
## Note: The PC variables have putative names based on the number of PCs included in the model.
## For example, instead of PC1, PC2, PC3 the actual PCs may be PC1, PC3, PC4

In the following examples that illustrate other GWA methods, we will run a smaller number of command except the section where running more than one algorithm is illustrated.

Summary statistics with rrBLUP

We test each SNP in the toy dataset for association with the main phenotype (BMI) given age, sex and case/control status, along with 1 PC. Below, we run rrBLUP independently just to get summary statistics. Please note that rrBLUP is not suitable for binary or categorical variables. It works only with continuous variables.

data(toy,package="prisma")

gdsfile(toy) <- system.file(package="prisma","extdata","toy.gds")

# Only 1 PC will be returned because of dataset size
toy <- suppressWarnings(calcPcaCovar(toy,method="snprel"))
## Performing PCA to select covariates to include in associations
## Reading GDS file /tmp/RtmpezHjqb/temp_libpath372f48f1c2bc/prisma/extdata/toy.gds...
## Performing LD pruning...
## SNP pruning based on LD:
## Excluding 0 SNP (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 38 SNPs (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 962
##     using 1 thread
##     sliding window: 500,000 basepairs, Inf SNPs
##     |LD| threshold: 0.2
##     method: composite
## Chromosome 18: 23.44%, 154/657
## Chromosome 21: 21.28%, 73/343
## 227 markers are selected in total.
## LD pruning finished! 227 SNPs will be used for PCA.
## 
## Performing PCA...
## Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on genotypes:
## Excluding 773 SNPs (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 0 SNP (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 227
##     using 1 thread
##     # of principal components: 32
## PCA:    the sum of all selected genotypes (0,1,2) = 10268
## CPU capabilities: Double-Precision SSE2
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:00 2022    (internal increment: 13024)
## 
[..................................................]  0%, ETC: ---        
[==================================================] 100%, completed, 0s
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:00 2022    Begin (eigenvalues and eigenvectors)
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:00 2022    Done.
## Selecting number of PCs to include
##   with Tracy-Widom test for significant eigenvalues
##     selected 1 PCs

rrSumstat <- gwaBlup(toy,response="BMI",
    covariates=c("Age","Gender"),usepc="rrint",npcs=1)
## 
## Preparing genotypes for rrBLUP...
## Performing GWAS with rrBLUP model
## Trait(s)    : BMI
## Covariate(s): Age, Gender
## Use PCs     : Yes
## Found 55 associations (uncorrected p-values).

The contents of the rrSumstat matrix:

head(rrSumstat)
##                 snp chrom bp        BMI        effect      pvalue

## rs1940646 rs1940646    NA NA 0.53061081  2.095420e-08 0.294706141
## rs1940651 rs1940651    NA NA 2.57551170 -6.830224e-08 0.002657592
## rs1940658 rs1940658    NA NA 1.31138453 -4.537714e-08 0.048821989
## rs1940670 rs1940670    NA NA 1.33929350  5.995759e-08 0.045783237
## rs1954825 rs1954825    NA NA 0.01160779 -1.675637e-08 0.973626111

Also, rrBLUP without PCs:

rrSumstat <- gwaBlup(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),
    usepc="none")
## 
## Preparing genotypes for rrBLUP...
## Performing GWAS with rrBLUP model
## Trait(s)    : BMI
## Covariate(s): Age, Gender
## Use PCs     : No
## Found 48 associations (uncorrected p-values).

Summary statistics with statgenGWAS

We test each SNP in the toy dataset for association with similar settings as the previous examples.

data(toy,package="prisma")

gdsfile(toy) <- system.file(package="prisma","extdata","toy.gds")

# Only 1 PC will be returned because of dataset size
toy <- suppressWarnings(calcPcaCovar(toy,method="snprel"))
## Performing PCA to select covariates to include in associations
## Reading GDS file /tmp/RtmpezHjqb/temp_libpath372f48f1c2bc/prisma/extdata/toy.gds...
## Performing LD pruning...
## SNP pruning based on LD:
## Excluding 0 SNP (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 38 SNPs (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 962
##     using 1 thread
##     sliding window: 500,000 basepairs, Inf SNPs
##     |LD| threshold: 0.2
##     method: composite
## Chromosome 18: 23.44%, 154/657
## Chromosome 21: 21.28%, 73/343
## 227 markers are selected in total.
## LD pruning finished! 227 SNPs will be used for PCA.
## 
## Performing PCA...
## Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on genotypes:
## Excluding 773 SNPs (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 0 SNP (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 227
##     using 1 thread
##     # of principal components: 32
## PCA:    the sum of all selected genotypes (0,1,2) = 10268
## CPU capabilities: Double-Precision SSE2
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:05 2022    (internal increment: 13024)

[..................................................]  0%, ETC: ---        
[==================================================] 100%, completed, 0s
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:05 2022    Begin (eigenvalues and eigenvectors)
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:05 2022    Done.
## Selecting number of PCs to include
##   with Tracy-Widom test for significant eigenvalues
##     selected 1 PCs

sgSumstat <- gwaStatgen(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),
    pcs=TRUE)
##

Summary statistics with SNPTEST

We test each SNP in the toy dataset for association with similar settings as the previous examples.

data(toy,package="prisma")

gdsfile(toy) <- system.file(package="prisma","extdata","toy.gds")

# Only 1 PC will be returned because of dataset size
toy <- suppressWarnings(calcPcaCovar(toy,method="snprel"))
## Performing PCA to select covariates to include in associations
## Reading GDS file /tmp/RtmpezHjqb/temp_libpath372f48f1c2bc/prisma/extdata/toy.gds...
## Performing LD pruning...
## SNP pruning based on LD:
## Excluding 0 SNP (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 38 SNPs (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 962
##     using 1 thread
##     sliding window: 500,000 basepairs, Inf SNPs
##     |LD| threshold: 0.2
##     method: composite
## Chromosome 18: 23.44%, 154/657
## Chromosome 21: 21.28%, 73/343
## 227 markers are selected in total.
## LD pruning finished! 227 SNPs will be used for PCA.
## 
## Performing PCA...
## Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on genotypes:
## Excluding 773 SNPs (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 0 SNP (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 227
##     using 1 thread
##     # of principal components: 32
## PCA:    the sum of all selected genotypes (0,1,2) = 10268
## CPU capabilities: Double-Precision SSE2
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:06 2022    (internal increment: 13024)
## 
[..................................................]  0%, ETC: ---        
[==================================================] 100%, completed, 0s
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:06 2022    Begin (eigenvalues and eigenvectors)
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:06 2022    Done.
## Selecting number of PCs to include
##   with Tracy-Widom test for significant eigenvalues
##     selected 1 PCs

if (Sys.which("snptest") != "") {
    snpSumstat <- gwaSnptest(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),
        pcs=TRUE)
} else {
    snpSumstat <- matrix()
}

SNPTEST with a dominant effect model and adding Case_Control as covariate:

if (Sys.which("snptest") != "") {
    snpSumstat <- gwaSnptest(toy,response="BMI",
        covariates=c("Age","Gender","Case_Control"),pcs=TRUE)
} else {
    snpSumstat <- matrix()
}

SNPTEST with Case_Control as the phenotype. In this case we must convert the Case_Control values from 1 and 2 to 0 and 1 as SNPTEST complains...

p <- phenotypes(toy)
p$Case_Control2 <- p$Case_Control
p$Case_Control2[p$Case_Control==1] <- 0
p$Case_Control2[p$Case_Control==2] <- 1
phenotypes(toy) <- p

if (Sys.which("snptest") != "") {
    snpSumstat <- gwaSnptest(toy,response="Case_Control2",
        covariates=c("Age","Gender","BMI"),pcs=TRUE)
} else {
    snpSumstat <- matrix()
}
## snptest operations will be executed at /tmp/RtmpPHwuf6/snptest_OGHNM0655C
## Preparing SNPTEST association run at workspace directory: /tmp/RtmpPHwuf6/snptest_OGHNM0655C

Summary statistics with PLINK

We test each SNP in the toy dataset for association with similar settings as the previous examples.

gdsfile(toy) <- system.file(package="prisma","extdata","toy.gds")

# Only 1 PC will be returned because of dataset size
toy <- suppressWarnings(calcPcaCovar(toy,method="snprel"))

Summary statistics with more than one test

Here we demonstrate the usage of the gwa() function which wraps over many tests for summary statistic acquisition and regsiters the results in the respective GWASExperiment slots. We test each SNP in the toy dataset for association with the main phenotype (BMI) given age, sex and case/control status, along with 1 PC. We also try additional associations with several tests and register them to the toy dataset.

data(toy,package="prisma")

gdsfile(toy) <- system.file(package="prisma","extdata","toy.gds")

# Only 1 PC will be returned because of dataset size
toy <- suppressWarnings(calcPcaCovar(toy,method="snprel"))
## Performing PCA to select covariates to include in associations
## Reading GDS file /tmp/RtmpezHjqb/temp_libpath372f48f1c2bc/prisma/extdata/toy.gds...
## Performing LD pruning...
## SNP pruning based on LD:
## Excluding 0 SNP (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 38 SNPs (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 962
##     using 1 thread
##     sliding window: 500,000 basepairs, Inf SNPs
##     |LD| threshold: 0.2
##     method: composite
## Chromosome 18: 23.44%, 154/657
## Chromosome 21: 21.28%, 73/343
## 227 markers are selected in total.
## LD pruning finished! 227 SNPs will be used for PCA.
## 
## Performing PCA...
## Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on genotypes:
## Excluding 773 SNPs (non-autosomes or non-selection)
## Excluding 0 SNP (monomorphic: TRUE, MAF: NaN, missing rate: NaN)
##     # of samples: 100
##     # of SNPs: 227
##     using 1 thread
##     # of principal components: 32
## PCA:    the sum of all selected genotypes (0,1,2) = 10268
## CPU capabilities: Double-Precision SSE2
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:54 2022    (internal increment: 13024)
## 
[..................................................]  0%, ETC: ---        
[==================================================] 100%, completed, 0s
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:54 2022    Begin (eigenvalues and eigenvectors)
## Mon Jun  6 20:33:54 2022    Done.
## Selecting number of PCs to include
##   with Tracy-Widom test for significant eigenvalues
##     selected 1 PCs

if (Sys.which("snptest") != "") {
    toy <- gwa(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),pcs=TRUE,
        psig=0.05,methods=c("glm","statgen","snptest"))
} else {
    toy <- gwa(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),pcs=TRUE,
        psig=0.05,methods=c("glm","statgen"))
}

Now, use the listGwa() function to see what test results are attached to the toy object:

listGwa(toy)
## 1 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Gender | PCs: 1
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Gender + PC1 + [SNP]
## 2 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Gender | PCs: -
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Gender + [SNP]
## 3 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Case_Control, Gender | PCs: 1
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Case_Control + Gender + PC1 + [SNP]
## 4 -> Phenotype: BMI | Covariates: Age, Case_Control, Gender | PCs: -
##      Putative formula: BMI ~ Age + Case_Control + Gender + [SNP]
## 5 -> Phenotype: Case_Control | Covariates: Age, BMI, Gender | PCs: 1
##      Putative formula: Case_Control ~ Age + BMI + Gender + PC1 + [SNP]
## 6 -> Phenotype: Case_Control | Covariates: Age, BMI, Gender | PCs: -
##      Putative formula: Case_Control ~ Age + BMI + Gender + [SNP]
## 
## Note: The PC variables have putative names based on the number of PCs included in the model.
## For example, instead of PC1, PC2, PC3 the actual PCs may be PC1, PC3, PC4

Let's see the effects and p-values for some of the attached models. Let's start with the first one where the phenotype was BMI and the covariates were Age and Gender along with 1 PC:

p <- pvalues(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),npcs=1)
head(p)
##                  glm    statgen   snptest      fisher
## rs1009238 0.31647832 0.31646353 0.3123870 0.327451895
## rs1940646 0.47598195 0.47596004 0.4659020 0.609719029
## rs1940651 0.03940511 0.03940241 0.0382558 0.003449833
## rs1940658 0.16900001 0.16898846 0.1627990 0.096683730
## rs1940670 0.21059720 0.21060807 0.2171560 0.158151740
## rs1954825 0.78810519 0.78809447 0.7877990 0.964036429

e <- effects(toy,response="BMI",covariates=c("Age","Gender"),npcs=1)
head(e)
##                  glm    statgen    snptest
## rs1009238 -0.6695782 -0.6696046 -0.1357960
## rs1940646  0.4810455  0.4810737  0.1001220
## rs1940651 -1.4435680 -1.4435983 -0.2962890
## rs1940658 -0.9054984 -0.9055274 -0.1868070
## rs1940670  0.8641098  0.8640962  0.1679460
## rs1954825  0.1746603  0.1746709  0.0347602

You will notice that the is an additional column named fisher to the matrix of p-values. This represents the combined p-value out of three tests using the Fisher's p-value combination method. The e matrix provides the regression coefficients for each method and SNP. These are used later for the calculation of weighted PRSs.

Furthermore, let's access the case where the phenotype was BMI and the covariates were Age, Gender and Case_Control with no PCs:
